True damage is fine in most current cases. There are a few questionable ones that make you think "why?" though.

Most of them make sense, but there are a couple that are just plain weird, yeah.

Why does Zoe's E do true damage?

Like, it's just plain misleading.

The proc damage on her E *is* reduced by resistances, since it doubles the *post mitigation value* of whatever hit woke the guy up.
if zoe didn't have true damage on E tanks would forever cockblock her spells with 0 consequences

That's the thing, it effectively *isn't* true damage.

It's the same damage type as whatever woke the guy up, since it multiplies the post mitigation value.

There are certain things that should be true though. And "true" isnt bad, when done *correctly*.

Example: True damage is a tank shredding tool, that certain people have because their damage potential would be otherwise unable to scale with the defensive potential. Ahri having it on her return stroke of Q is fair, since the tanks have plenty of time to dodge the return, if not the whole thing. Cho's execute dealing true damage is fair in the sense that it's an execute, meaning you have to effectively land everything else probably multiple times before it's useful. If the enemy isn't low enough, it's not going to kill anyway and you're using an ultimate ability at that point without the payoff. Plus, you have to be in melee range to use it, and he's a giant freaking monster whose entire design is to consume everything. Pretty sure being eaten alive would be pretty much exactly that bad.

Shaco's invisibility is fair because in many cases, he's using it reactively, or as a way to engage a gank. Though it's pretty toxic when paired with such a short cd blink, the invis part isn't the problem there...and honestly, there's another who's like 5x worse. Shaco is more annoying than unfair.

But then...you get to the point it's not used correctly. Post 16 Kayle just casually throwing true damage around like Halloween candy. Vayne dealing %hp true damage while damn near permanently invis and untargetable. That moment they had to change Akali because her "obscurity" or whatever-the-hell they called it was allowing her to bully people under their own towers without taking any damage. Wind Wall's 4 seconds of true nullifying any projectiles from any direction while the cocky bastard murders entire teams since half the enemy can't even hit him anymore. Certain things, yes, are just entirely uncalled for.

How tf is Cho'gath nuking people and being able to do well over half a squishy's health by pressing a single point and click button fair, but Vayne's DPS isn't?

It doesn't even have execute scaling. It's just a nuke that does a shitton of damage and is *used* to kill, but is not itself truly an execute. Actual executes are things like Veigar's R (damage scales as they get lower), Kindred's E (automatically does bonus damage when the enemy's under a certain percent of health), Urgot's R (Literally only kills if they're below a certain % of health) or Pyke (Becomes true damage if they're below a certain amount of health).

Just being used to kill doesn't make it an actual execute.

True Damage existing reduces total damage in the game.

If you want something to deal 100 damage to a tank that takes 50% reduced damage, that same ability will do 150 damage to a squishy who only takes 25% reduced damage. 

It gets even worse when you realize that 100 damage is only 1/30th the tanks total HP pool if they have 3000 HP, where as the 150 is 1/13th of a squishy's total HP pool at 2k HP, making it far worse than just a 50 damage difference.

Where as if you have true damage, you are just doing 100 to everything, meaning squishies are taking less damage total than they would have taken to make tanks take the same damage.

What makes him a fair champion is how he has to land 3 separate abilities to apply his true damage. The only thing his aa can do is prolong the passive proc before expiring.

The true damage research passive is a part of his core design. however, that being the case, they could stand to nerf him *slightly* so that he has to lean a little more on stacking his research passive instead of just nuking everything from orbit with high af AP ratios.

That research concept could definitely be applied in other ways. I remember playing velkoz when you didn’t even care about that passive, you just build magic pen and operated around your base damages. 

I mean, I do enjoy velkoz as he is now, but I definitely get the feeling that he is perhaps a little too well rounded at _everything_. Poke? Check. Burst? Check. Dps? Check. Squishy killing? Check. Tank shredding? Check. CC? Check. Waveclear? Check. High high range? Check. Low mana costs? Check. The only thing he lacks is mobility.

Fine then. Here's where my specialty comes in with that squid.
Vel'Koz's passive requires him to land 3 abilities to proc his true damage and have the enemy "researched" so that his ulti can be more deadly. Its early game damage isn't that much until he gains enough AP in the mid game all the way to late game.
His Q set cast is slow af but 2nd cast it's fast but due to its 1st travel it's often easy to dodge its 2nd cast (that's if you're aiming geometrically). And slows at a decent amount.
His w is 2 wave ability. 1st wave explosion does little damage while 2nd wave explosion does increased damage but can be easily dodged.
His e is a short knock up, pretty low ranged compared to his Q and W and to get to its range is often a big danger for Vel'Koz.
His ulti is a magic damage laser that slows but not compared to his Q. It's a scary ulti but not always too threatening unless the passive has been proced which makes the ulti from magic into a true damage.

Vel'Koz requires to land combos upon combos to dish out his damage. Usually the ideal method for many vel players is landing Q 1st in order to get an easy access to landing the e and W (or 2nd wave of the w). While the number of combos for Vel'Koz are quite at a decent amount, it's easier said than done to land the combos ESPECIALLY how easily they can be dodged from either vision, utility, mobility or even a mistake like wrong timing.

That's why it's not often recommended to simply ulti in without passive proc (unless fed) and Vel'Koz needs a ton of AP to be deadly. The main elements that makes Vel'Koz a fair champ is he lacks mobility and is a glass cannon and high mobility champions are his worst nightmare. Melees can melt him if they get in range and his ulti can be disrupted by cc.
To the end of the point, his true damage is part of his identity as a champion since he is literally researching his enemy to find out their weaknesses and once he does, he knows how to hurt them. Research goes to his passive and exposed weakness to his advantage goes to his ulti, that's lore wise as well as gameplay wise.
